Award.AwardTitle: Support for Young Researchers to attend the 2016 Intelligent Tutoring Systems Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cyberlearning and Future Learning Technologies Program funds efforts that will help envision the next generation of learning technologies and advance what we know about how people learn in technology-rich environments. Cyberlearning CAP projects build capacity for research and development in the field of Cyberlearning by improving technical infrastructure, human capital, and in other ways. The Intelligent Tutoring Systems (ITS) 2016 conference offers a rare professional opportunity for interdisciplinary students to converge and present cutting-edge research from the fields of artificial intelligence (AI), learning science, computer science, cognitive and learning sciences, psychology, and educational technology.

This project supports travel for selected advanced graduate students to attend the doctoral consortium at the ITS 2016 conference in Croatia. The conference has a special Young Research Track within the main conference for advanced graduate students. In this track a special session supports students to share their research with papers, posters, tutorials, workshops, and informal interactions with accomplished researchers. Students present their research ideas and receive feedback from researchers in the ITS community. An important goal of the doctoral consortium is to build the new generation of researchers in the forward-looking technical area of intelligent tutoring systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nine United States graduate students participated in, helped to write, and/or presented papers at the the 2017 conferences on Artifiicial Intelligence and Education (AIED) and Educartional Data Mining (EDM) in Wuhan, China. Students attended one or both conferences. The AIED 2017 conference promoted rigorous research and development of interactive and adaptive learning environments for learners of all ages, for subject matter that spanned the school curriculum (e.g., math, science, language learning), and for professional applications in industry, military, and medicine. The EDM 2017 conference promoted scientific research in the interdisciplinary field of educational data mining, concerned with developing methods for exploring the unique types of data that come from educational settings, and using those methods to better understand students and the settings in which they learn. EDM research activities are aimed at applying data mining to analyze data generated by various information systems that support learning or education (in schools, colleges, universities, other academic or professional learning institutions, and informal settings). 

Each United States student delivered a talk at the doctoral consortium (DC) or in the main conference of their attended conference, also included a written 2-page statement about the benefits of the conference for their research or broader PhD experience and indicated which parts of the conference might have an impact on their research and career trajectory. Reports from 7 United States doctoral students were included in the second year NSF report.  In addition, students attended the Doctoral Consortium events and networked with other PhD students and mentors (at AIED, during the lightening talks at the DC session and at lunch; at EDM during the DC session).

Students who participated in the Doctoral Consortiuum produced close to a dozen conference papers that were published by a well-vetted publisher (Springer in the case of AIED 2017) and on the website of EDM 2017, in additon to be presented in a well-established conference. The Doctoral Consortium Track provided a rigorous application process and selection criteria, scheduled events at the conference for recipients, and included person-to-person meetings between students and mentors.

Students submitted papers electronically to the AIED 2017 and EDM 2017 Doctoral Consortium submission system through the Easychair system and formatted their papers as for the conference. Students had several opportunities to publish their work. Papers accepted in the main conference were published in the main conference proceedings. Each student had 10 pages in the proceedings. Accepted papers were allocated presentation time in the main conference or in the Doctoral Consortium.

Students discussed their work during their allocated time.

Originanlly this NSF award was supposed to support 15-18 advanced doctoral students from the United States to attend the International Conference on Intelligent Tutoring Systems (ITS) to be held in Croatia, from June 6-10, 2016. So few people applied to attend this conference that no students requested support. 

The Office of Grants and Contract (OGCA) at UMass give us permission to use the NSF funding for United States graduate students to attend the sister conference during the next summer, June 2017 (Artifical Intelligence and Education (AIED 2017) and Educational Data Mining (EDM 2017) to be held in Wuhan, China. We  received permission from OGCA and established a procedure for USA students to receive funding if they applied for the Doctoral Consortium in AIED 2017 and EDM 2017.
